oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery interviews Dolly Parton - Live - Part 2
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Dolly Parton (performer) for Ralph Emery: On the Record With Dolly Parton. Recording is performed in front of a live audience. Recording is from September 29, 1994. Tape is labeled part 2.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Dolly Parton; Kenny Rogers;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) An unidentified voice says "Did we think would sell, but we" -- (00:04) An unidentified voice says "Hot off the press. Box 9500" -- (00:13) Dolly Parton and Emery joke to the audience pre-recording -- (01:03) Emery introduces Kenny Rogers, and Rogers claims Parton and Emery are having too much fun -- (01:55) Emery has Rogers recall when he first met Parton; Rogers praises Parton for her consistency -- (03:03) Rogers declares that it was Barry Gibb's idea to have Rogers work with Parton; Parton and Rogers reflect on people associating both to each other -- (05:40) Parton and Emery joke about "This is Your Life" -- (05:52) Parton asks for an unidentified man's flowers -- (06:44) Emery introduces Parton's first book; additionally, Emery inquires about Parton's relationship with Carl Dean -- (09:16) Emery asks Parton about what attracted Parton to Dean -- (10:39) Parton discusses how she got married in Ringgold, Georgia the night before an interview with Emery -- (13:41) Emery invites Parton to address her time with Porter Wagoner; Parton praises Wagoner, despite their differences -- (15:03) Emery addresses a point in Parton's book where she reflects on the difficulties of working with Wagoner -- (17:19) Emery inquires about the time at which Parton wrote "I Will Always Love You" -- (20:30) Emery and Parton discuss how Sandy Gallin managed Parton when she moved to California; additionally, Parton reflects on how she approached her acting career -- (23:02) Emery leads Parton to the time Dean met Jane Fonda on the set of Nine to Five -- (24:53) Parton describes Steel Magnolias to be the best movie she had worked on -- (26:26) Emery readdresses Nine to Five, and Emery wishes Parton to recall her streaking story -- (30:12) Emery inquires about the major influence of a church that Parton would go to in her youth -- (31:50) Parton reflects on the time she lost her faith
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Emery, Ralph; Parton, Dolly; Parton, Dolly, 1946-; Rogers, Kenny;
